subject: implement async handlers for all requester commands
commitMessage:
implement async handlers for all requester commands

this commit makes use of 74f27c730ef3925a0f2a3adfaa04f8790f931372 to
convert the existing blocking requester commands in pldm to async
ones.
this is tested with Host code and seems to work fine

Change-Id: I8d4762c3cd5bce49f854b30f8325bfcd1dcb4ff9
Signed-off-by: Sampa Misra <sampmisr@in.ibm.com>

Change has been successfully merged by ManojKiran Eda
can the commit message have some more info?
remove
Ack
nit: no change in this file, can you add back the line?
not sure why this is showing up. compared with the merged code as well, the file looks same

"if(rc || completionCode)" would be less characters.

might apply for other portions of this patch.
Ack

if (rc)

might apply for other portions of this patch.
Ack
It will be good to evaluate the InternalFailure thrown here, in general we have limited the use of InternalFailure.
Done
My preference will be separate conditions for a decode failure and error completion code. The trace statement looks messed up :-)
Done
Do we want this to be consistent? DbusToPLDMEvent is passing a reference.
yeah i had to change that to make the testcase passed. changing all to reference
I think you have changed all to pointer instead of changing all to reference. I think it is mixed up already in code for passing global objects, example Requester* and Requester&.

yeah i have changed all to pointers to keep parity among the functions as you suggested.
can not pass the reference because in few cases like "pldm::host_effecters::HostEffecterParser"  we have testcases written and passing a null reference fails the testcase
the same is being followed for "dbusImplReq" as well. in general that is a reference but in few cases it is a pointer
Why this indirect routing from fetchPDRResponseHandler ->processHostPDRs  ? The response handler for GetPDR can be processHostPDRs.

i understand the code as: for each request that bmc sends, a new fetchPDRResponseHandler is created. in that case we can not do the processing of the PDRs in the handler. we need to remember the previous record handle and few other stuffs.
one more reason to separate this out is to maintain better clarity since processing the PDR is bit detailed

> for each request that bmc sends, a new fetchPDRResponseHandler is created. in that case we can not do the processing of the PDRs in the handler.

The lambda is just providing an indirection it does not provide abstraction. You should be able to register processHostPDRs in the registerRequest and remove fetchPDRResponseHandler.
done
Is this involves sending a PLDM request message to host, this can be synchronous. I don't see a value in Deferring it.
yeah this sends a request to Host. this has to be deferred otherwise we donot send response from the current command

We typically defer when action for a request is long running(BMC is responder) so respond with a PLDM response and then do the long running action.

In this case BMC is the requester and is processing the response of GetPDR, so what is the need to defer sending the RepoChanged Event?

I think there is no need to defer this logic as well. (below)

>        deferredFetchPDREvent = std::make_unique<sdeventplus::source::Defer>(
            event,
            std::bind(std::mem_fn((&HostPDRHandler::_processFetchPDREvent)),
                      this, nextRecordHandle, std::placeholders::_1));

this is the case where bmc should respond to the previous command before sending it's own request
we already faced issue where Host hangs when we request a new command instead of responding to the previous command
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/pldm/+/41113
with the above commit
also does adding a deferred event cause any performance issue?

i am not sure if that works with HB. they are not running with async and we are already seeing few hang issues in ipl which had to be solved with the defer events. just do not want to increase another chance. may be i can give a try but if it does not cause a performance hit then what is the harm in keeping?

> they are not running with async
It shouldn't matter what is on the other side, as long as we are sticking to the timing/retry requirements in the PLDM base specification. To summarize the hang issue, Case 1) it was when PLDM daemon blocked on a request and waiting for response from the other side and Case 2) PLDM daemon not serving as the responder for other requests. With adopting async request/response, Case1 will not happen anymore.

> may be i can give a try but if it does not cause a performance hit then what is the harm in keeping?
My concern is that since Defer has solved a hang issue in a certain situation, we don't use that indiscriminately and without thought. If you see a deadlock situation that can arise, we can consider this approach.

Hi Tom,
I understand your point but would request you to +1 this and may be i can put up a new commit removing the deferred stuff. the reason being, this change is running in GHE for quite some time now and lot of other commits are in queue to get merged after this one.
it will be good if i can create a separate commit for removing the deferred stuff and run for significant cycles in DVT before getting that merged
Ok, I am fine with a follow up commit.
At least this should be renamed at a first look, there are already 3 function names fetchPDR/_fetchPDR/fetchPDRsOnStart, as well as improve the documentation around this.
Ack
missing doxygen
Done
Source files are typically added as dependency, why hpp?
i guess there was some compilation error in building test cases. will check once more
Why this change? I guess it is unintended.
